title: How to Clean an Extractor Fan

methods.name: Wiping Down a Bathroom Vent Fan

steps.headline: Turn the power to the fan off at the circuit breaker or switch.
steps.description: This is to make sure the fan doesn’t come on as you’re cleaning it, causing you harm. Switch the power to off at the switch in the bathroom, or go to your circuit breaker and turn off the power for that room. Circuit breakers are usually found in the basement or garage, though sometimes they’re on the outside of your house.

steps.headline: Remove the vent cover using the springs or screw.
steps.description: If your vent cover is spring loaded, place your hands on either side of the vent and simply pull down to remove it. If there’s a screw in the center of the vent, use a screwdriver to remove the screw and release the vent cover. A spring-loaded cover will have clips on the inside that you squeeze to remove the vent cover fully.

steps.headline: Vacuum or rinse the dust and dirt off of the vent cover.
steps.description: If the vent cover has lots of dirt in its crevices, consider rinsing it with warm water and using an old toothbrush to scrub it clean. Otherwise, using a bristle brush attachment on a vacuum will clean it thoroughly. Vacuum both sides of the vent cover, paying special attention to the indentations. If you rinse the vent cover off with water, dry it thoroughly with a clean towel before reinstalling it.

steps.headline: Clean the inside of the fan housing using a vacuum attachment.
steps.description: Use the bristle brush attachment on the vacuum to clean the inside of the vent as well, sucking up any dirt or grime near the motor and along all the edges of the fan housing. Be thorough to make sure there’s as little dust and dirt left up there as possible. Stand on a stool or small ladder to reach the inside of the fan housing, if needed. If you don't have a vacuum, use a large paint brush or scrub brush to brush out the dirt in the vent, catching it with a dust tray or something similar.

steps.headline: Place the vent cover back into the ceiling once you’re finished.
steps.description: Once the extractor fan is all cleaned out, put your vent cover back over the vent just as you removed it. Hold down the spring-loaded clips to position the vent cover back in the ceiling, or use the screwdriver to reinstall the screw that holds the cover in place. Check to ensure the vent cover is flush against the ceiling so it’s properly reinstalled.

steps.headline: Clean the bathroom extractor fan every 6 months to 1 year.
steps.description: The bathroom extractor fan helps soak up moisture and grime so your bathroom doesn’t become moldy and dirty. Aim to clean the extractor in each bathroom that you have every 6 months to 1 year, depending on the size of the bathroom and how much it’s used. For example, if the bathroom is shared by multiple people and is used often, clean the extractor fan every 6 months.

steps.headline: Turn off the power to the extractor fan at the circuit breaker.
steps.description: This will ensure the fan doesn’t somehow turn on while you’re trying to clean it. Switch off the power by locating your circuit breaker and turning off the power to that specific room. Avoid cleaning the kitchen extractor fan right after you’ve used the stove so it isn’t too hot. The circuit breaker is often found in the garage or basement of a house.

steps.headline: Replace carbon or paper filters.
steps.description: These types of filters can't be washed, so you'll need to simply replace them with a brand new one when it's time. Carbon filters should be changed every 6 months, while paper filters should be replaced every month. Check the manufacturer's guide for your kitchen appliance for more detailed information about exactly which filter to purchase. Home improvement stores will have carbon or paper filters you can purchase, or you can buy them online.

steps.headline: Fill your sink with boiling water and dish soap.
steps.description: Plug your kitchen drain so that water gathers in the sink and fill it with super hot water. Squirt dish soap into the water and stir it around, creating soapy water. Use a mild dish soap that you would use for your regular dishes.

steps.headline: Remove the filter and let it soak if it’s able to go in water.
steps.description: Slide or pop the filter out of the underside of the hood. Inspect your filter to see what kind it is. A metal or sponge filter can be washed with soapy water, while a paper or carbon filter can’t be washed. If you have a metal or sponge filter, let it soak in the hot water for 10 minutes. If you have a carbon filter, replace it every 6 months. A paper filter is disposable and doesn’t need to be cleaned.

steps.headline: Scrub the filter to remove any leftover grease and grime.
steps.description: Use a soft cloth to rub off grease or dirt that’s stuck on the metal or sponge filter. Rinse the filter with clean water to remove any dirty remnants. Use a non-abrasive cloth or cleaning tool to scrub the filter.

steps.headline: Dry the filter thoroughly using a clean towel.
steps.description: Swipe a clean cloth or towel over the filter to dry it. Dry both sides and all the edges to ensure it’s as dry as possible before it’s put back into place. If you don’t have towels or cloths that you’d like to use on the filter, use paper towels instead.

steps.headline: Slide the filter back into the hood and wipe down the hood if necessary.
steps.description: Put the filter back into the underside of the hood just as you took it out once it’s clean. If the hood is dirty, wipe it down with a soapy cloth to get rid of dirt and grime before drying it. Use dish soap and warm water to clean the hood.

steps.headline: Clean your kitchen extractor fan every month.
steps.description: The grease builds up over time in the fan, so it’s important to clean the extractor once every month or so. Plan to clean it at a certain time each month, like on the first Saturday, so you always know when the last time you cleaned it was. If you don’t use your stovetop very often, you might clean it every other month instead.
